News has reached me that one of the people that I am trying to emulate from the airline industry, Sir Frederick Alfred Laker, has passed away today at age 83. I do hope that if I ever get enough Euros together, I will start my own SkyTrain service with the same funkiness (and cheap fares for the common folks) as Sir Freddie had intended. Should BA and that Irish jackass O'Leary get on my way, I will follow Sir Freddie's advice and "Sue the bastards!"

On the same night as the "Leaders' Debate" in YVR (See my comment at http://www.livejournal.com/users/dlkereluk/269063.html ), I sent off a webmail thing to the Blocheads that said (in proper English--I apologised for not being able to do it en Francais) that if they weren't separatists, and if they ran a candidate in my riding, that I would vote for the Bloc, given that much of what Duceppe had to say with regard to social policy mirrored what the "old" NDP used to espouse.

Apparently, the Blocheads forwarded a copy of my statement to the Canadian Press (an outfit not unlike the AP). I was aware that this could happen since these kinds of things are part of the public record. When asked how I was able to figure out how to send a comment to the Blocheads from a site that's written entirely en francais, I explained that when one sees something like "Plan du Site", clicks on it, and then below near the bottom of the page sees something entitled "Contacts", it doesn't take a PhD in the French language to figure out that's where one can send comments. All of those years of reading the bilingual labels on cereal boxes and detergent boxes have finally paid off.

I'm going to be talking a bit more about, well, sensitive adult type subjects relating to things that are listed in my user page. For the time being, I will put such posts behind a lj cut that says "Enter at own risk" or something to that effect. It might even be better at some point in time that if people still want to read my "adult" posts, that I can set up a special filter and people that want to be put in it can just ask me. I really don't want to have a special bi/gay journal or anything just because I want to explore that part of my life a lot more, since I am not ashamed of that. Some of the things that I do want to talk about may be a bit racy for people, so I am trying to take their feelings into consideration.

Piss on degrees in wheat from the University of Saskatchewan, in corn from the University of Iowa, in chickens from the University of Arkansas at Fayetteville, or in pineapples from the University of Hawaii at Manoa*, I am very pleased to inform you that you can obtain a degree intramolecular from cyberspace. Don't ask me exactly what a degree intramolecular is, but I do know that it is being offered, and that I'm happy to let you know about it.

(*By the way, all of these fine institutions could use donations for the services that they provide to the general public. The URLs for information about donating are http://www.usask.ca, http://www.uiowa.edu, http://www.uark.edu, and http://www.uhm.hawaii.edu. Alternatively, you can send a donation to a post secondary institution closer to where you live.*)

It's not a thing that I do very often because we all move onto different things in our lives, but I do like to drop in on the Live Journals of people that I've lost regular contact with. Whenever I do this, I'm anticipating that the lives of the people that I know will be a bit different and happier.

I read one journal today, in which this person (those who know both me and this person will know who I'm talking about) seems to have levelled out (mood and emotion wise), and is trying to make a good future for herself, notwithstanding the difficulties in her life. Yet, she has this fellow that seems to be cyberstalking her with posts about unrequited love, and all of those things. I hope that she's going to be safe.

Dear readers, I hope that each one of you takes caution to heart as you travel through cyberspace.

Oy, it'd be wonderful if "people" would let me know about changes in communities. I am not terribly concerned that the changes have been made, but at the very least, I'd like to have been informed so that when I go to edit something, I don't freak out because I can't get in to do the relevant editing.

I really cannot take it anymore, but since I have this overwhelming desire to live, well, the extended period of sleep option is the only one that I have.

The people of the United States are starting to speak out against the actions of the junta in Washington. I knew that my faith in the great, silent majority was not misplaced! :) U.S. communities join growing revolt against expanded police powers BETH GORHAM Updated at 18:34 on October 14, 2003, EST http://mysask.sympatico.ca/portal/generic.jsp?beanID=634&viewID=storyRenderer&targetDocument=w101471A.xml&topic=World WASHINGTON (CP) - It started as a quiet trickle. Now it's a flood. Dozens of U.S. communities are defying the administration of President George W. Bush by passing resolutions condemning the Patriot Act, a sweeping revision of surveillance laws intended to help catch terrorists. Critics say the act, passed just weeks after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, gives federal authorities unlimited power to spy on Americans and has been widely used outside its mandate to pursue drug traffickers and others in hundreds of non-terrorism cases. Officials counter that expanded police powers have also uncovered several suspected terrorist cells. Attorney General John Ashcroft, in several speeches defending the act, says it's been used to prevent death and destruction on American soil. While the resolutions have no legal force to prevent federal tactics, many make clear that local police won't play along. Detroit, for one, has directed its police to refrain from collecting information about someone's political, religious or social views unless it directly relates to a criminal investigation. Montgomery County, a sprawling Maryland jurisdiction of one million people, passed a resolution last month at the urging of local groups concerned about policing in a racially-tense post-9-11 climate. "The Muslim community believes they are specifically targeted," Councillor George Leventhal said Tuesday. "I have a lot of good friends who just happen to worship in a mosque and would never dream of harming another soul. "What we're trying to do is send a message of solidarity to all of our citizens." The USA Patriot Act gave the FBI new powers to secretly access medical records, reading habits, religious affiliations, even Internet surfing and personal belongings. With the second anniversary of the act approaching, nearly 200 communities and three states have passed resolutions that back civil liberties, with some calling for a rollback of the act's most contentious provisions. Civil and immigrant rights groups are gathering this weekend in Silver Spring, Md., for a major conference geared to increasing the groundswell of opposition. "Many communities are recognizing that the actual nature of the war on terrorism is becoming a war on immigration," said Damon Moglen at the Washington office of the American Civil Liberties Union. "People wearing certain clothes and going to certain places of worship are targeted. That's called racial profiling." Bush wants the act expanded, saying there are "unreasonable obstacles" to pursuing suspected terrorists. Specifically, he's proposed allowing subpoenas to be issued without a judge's consent, holding suspects without bail and pursuing the death penalty in acts of sabotage that result in death. And a bill introduced in the House of Representatives in July would extend responsibility for enforcing immigrations laws to state and local police. Montgomery County's resolution, like Alaska's, includes a provision saying police won't request anyone's immigration status. "It's not (our) job," said Leventhal, "to harass people who may not have their immigration papers in perfect order." Some of the resolutions ask federal authorities for information on how the act is being implemented and whether it has been effective since there's been little public data. That lack of information has compounded the problem, said Moglen. "The U.S. people are being told there's an unending war against terrorism but they have no idea how it's being waged in their communities. It makes them deeply suspicious and deeply concerned." Defence Secretary Donald Rumsfeld says suspected terrorists at a U.S. prison camp at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, will likely be detained without trials for as long at the anti-terrorism war lasts. "I think this has to be equated with some very sordid moments in American history, like the McCarthy era and detaining Japanese Americans in the Second World War," said Moglen. "We are living in the midst of a very frightening pendulum swing."

I have been engaged in a discussion regarding various methods of paying for health care services. Needless to say, I am quite happy with the services that I am being provided, and the way that they are being paid for. I am aware, though, that there are people to the south of me that do not have such benefits. This is very unfortunate, because except for a few morons located at (and in the vincinity of) 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington DC, they really are good people.

What is especially troubling to me is that something like 40 million people in this country are without health care coverage. 
Part time workers and the self employed are put in a difficult position, as are people who work for very small businesses. For example, a person that works at this one company that I will be providing a brief write up on at the end of this message is SOL when it comes to health insurance. As for people who work at small businesses, the owners of these enterprises are having a hard enough time as it is keeping afloat, let alone providing health care benefits for their valued employees. One would expect a large, profitable company to provide some assistance to part time exployees, but nobody with any degree of sense in their head would expect a shop owned by Ma and Pa in Beebe, Arkansas (it rhymes!) to come up with enough cash to provide the same level of benefits to their employees.

Ok, as I promised, here is the blurb that I promised about the large company that is bereft of decent health care benefits for its part timers: (Keep in mind that a health employee is a productive employee, notwithstanding what you might otherwise be told by corporate executives.)

"The Company today reported earnings from continuing operations of $140 million, or 42 cents per diluted share, for the quarter ended Aug. 30, 2003, an increase of more than 75 percent compared with $79 million, or 24 cents per diluted share, for the quarter ended Aug. 31, 2002.
    Based on recent performance trends, the Company raised its guidance for earnings from continuing operations for fiscal 2004 to a range of $2.35 to $2.40 per diluted share, compared with $1.91 per diluted share in fiscal 2003 and a current analysts' consensus estimate of $2.38 per share.
    'I am very pleased with the outstanding earnings growth we achieved in the second quarter. The credit goes to our employees, who worked hard to improve our gross profit rate while boosting efficiency and productivity. In addition, our team translated increased consumer confidence as well as tax refunds into strong growth in comparable store sales for the quarter, particularly during the back-to-school season. Their superior execution drove our market share gains in the quarter,' said Brad Anderson, vice chairman and CEO. 'September has started off with a comparable store sales gain in the double digits, similar to that of August. While it is unlikely that the recent level of comparable store sales growth is sustainable for the duration of the year, we hope to extend our market-share gains in the second half by continuing to deliver industry-leading comparable store sales gains. We also expect to translate those market-share gains into profit growth through our close focus on margins and expenses during the holiday selling season.'

    Revenue and Productivity Gains Drive Expense Leverage

    Revenue from continuing operations for the second quarter of fiscal 2004 increased 17 percent to $5.4 billion, driven by a comparable store sales gain of 7.5 percent and the addition of 74 new stores in the past 12 months.
    The gross profit rate for continuing operations rose to 25.4 percent of revenue in the second quarter, an increase of 0.5 percent of revenue compared with the second quarter of fiscal 2003. The improvement in the gross profit rate was driven by a 30-percent comparable store sales gain in digital products, which generally have a higher gross profit rate than analog products; sharper promotional strategies; and more effective management of product life cycles.
    The SG&A expense rate for continuing operations was 21.2 percent of revenue for the second quarter, compared with 22.2 percent of revenue for the second quarter of fiscal 2003. The large improvement in the SG&A expense rate was driven by leverage achieved on the 7.5 percent comparable store sales gain and new stores added in the past 12 months. The SG&A rate also benefited from lower corporate and field office headcount as well as other administrative and overhead cost reductions stemming from the Company's efficiency initiatives.
    Operating income from continuing operations rose to 4.2 percent of revenue for the second quarter of fiscal 2004, compared with 2.8 percent of revenue for the second quarter of fiscal 2003. Net interest expense was $3 million, comparable to the $2 million net interest expense for the same quarter last year. The Company's effective tax rate in the second quarter of fiscal 2004 was 38.3 percent, slightly lower than the effective rate in the second quarter of fiscal 2003, primarily due to a lower effective state income-tax rate."

The following is an email that I sent off to the idiots that are running CANADIAN National, as well as a few politicians that previously expressed an interest in these matters:
"It's becoming more apparent with each passing day that the IC cabal at CN HQ in Montreal is beginning to lose its grip on reality. Not only are these "gentlemen" entirely clueless about how to run a CANADIAN railway, they are also CLUELESS about public relations and how to bring about change in a way that the general public can "buy into." The latest CN disaster under E. Hunter's "brilliant" reign is the edict that Canadian National employees refrain from using the word "Canadian" in corporate communications. If using the word "Canadian" in corporate communications is such a crime, then perhaps it is also a crime for Canadian National to have hired too many overpaid IC executives when there are plenty of qualified Canadians to do the work in a much more effective and efficient manner. This is a fact that Canadian immigration officials should be examining to see if any laws relating to the hiring of foreign executives when there are a sufficient number of Canadians available to do the work was broken.
 
As for Mark Hallman's baffling comment that E. Hunter's edict "...has absolutely nothing to do with nationalism. For our employees and our customer base we want to have a consistent brand identity and that is CN..." (http://sympatico.globeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20030919.wcanrail/front/Front/frontBN/sympatico-front ) how is it that Canadian Pacific, a railway with significant US operations recently changed its name from the generic "CP Railway" to "Canadian Pacific Railway"? As for Hallman's other comment that "...Canadian Pacific Railway has chosen CPR as its marketing name...", a quick visit to the Canadian Pacific Railway (http://www8.cpr.ca/cms/English/default.htm) website shows that the term "Canadian Pacific Railway" NOT CPR is featured prominently as the brand name. Before Hallman and E. Hunter spout off about brand recognition, perhaps they would do well to actually take a course in marketing and PR. It's very clear that the Canadian Pacific Railway has people that have some expertise in marketing and PR, which is not something that can be said about E. Hunter's "CN" or whatever he wants to call it this week (maybe it will be IC next week).
 
It might be wise for the government to consider the renationalisation of Canadian National, and send the IC cabal back from whence they came.
(A printed of this email will be sent to E. Hunter at Canadian National HQ in Montreal.
Email copies were sent to Mr. Bill Blaikie, M.P.--Winnipeg/Transcona, the Honourable David Collenette--Minister of Transport, and the Honourable Denis Coderre--Minister of Immigration and Citizenship [in regard to the hiring of former IC executives])"

The Globe and Mail (http://sympatico.globeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20030627.wcomm0627/front/Front/frontBN/sympatico-front) reported today that the Supreme Court of Canada struck down the very undemocratic law that prevented very valuable political groups like my beloved Rhinocerous Party from fielding candidates in federal elections. The ruling will allow my Party to "...to issue tax receipts for donations received outside the election period; the right of a candidate to transfer unspent election funds to the party rather than to the government; and the right of a party's candidates to list their party affiliation on ballot papers." As soon as the mechanics of all of the ruling are worked out, my fellow Rhinos (assuming they will leave the pubs that they happen to be at) and I will get our massive election machinery rolling. It takes a thousand clams to get each of our names on the ballot, so we will be hitting each of you up for donations in due course. It is a great day for demockracy in Canada! Darren "Big Rhino & 'Da Smart Ass from Kamsack' " Kereluk, Acting Leader, Rhinocerous Party of Canada Breezily putting the "mock" back into demockracy

"Saeed al-Sahaf, you may recall, provided a much-needed element of comic relief during the televised U.S. invasion of Iraq, repeatedly denying U.S. and British military advances, and even denying that U.S. forces had entered Baghdad when reporters were already seeing American military vehicles driving on local streets and when the sounds of battle could be heard from the hotel where press conferences were being held.... The guy was a flak. His job wasn't to tell the truth. It was to tell reporters whatever his bosses wanted him to tell them about the course of the invasion. Sort of like his White House counterpart Ari Fleischer. So was Viceroy Bremer planning on charging Saeed al-Sahaf with lying? That would be a good one, given what we know about the lies we were all told leading up to this war by British P.M. Tony Blair, President George Bush, V.P. DICK (emphasis added--mine) Cheney, Secretary of State Colin Powell, Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld, et al. There are two ways of approaching at this situation. Maybe we should encourage the military to go ahead and prosecute Saeed al-Sahaf for public lying. Then we could bring that concept home to the U.S. and bring similar charges against the whole Bush administration, using the legal concept of reciprocity. That would get a jump on Comical Ali, who could be counted on otherwise to adopt the defense of lying raised last Sunday in Bush's defense by the New York Times: "They all did it." And why stop there? We could go after the corporate flaks who routinely deny that their companies have engaged in malfeasance, corruption, pollution, labor law violations, safety violations, etc. Just going after the flaks for the tobacco, power and automotive industries alone for lying in public could keep an army of prosecutors busy for years. Alternatively, maybe it would be just as well to let U.S. authorities hypocritically go after Saeed al-Sahaf alone. The spectacle of watching someone be prosecuted and jailed just for telling whoppers might conceivably jar some jaded Americans into contemplating the state of affairs we've arrived at here at home, where lying by White House officials has become so routine that it no longer merits any notice or comment in the media or any condemnation by the public..."
